nexttext: The most general Higgs potential invariant under the global $SU(2)_L\times SU(2)_R\times U(1)_Y$ symmetry is
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\Phi=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}\phi^{0*}&\phi^{+}\\
-\phi^{-}&\phi^{0}\end{array}\right)~{},~{}~{}\Delta=\left(\begin{array}[]{ccc%
}\chi^{0*}&\xi^{+}&\chi^{++}\\
-\chi^{-}&\xi^{0}&\chi^{+}\\
\chi^{--}&-\xi^{-}&\chi^{0}\end{array}\right)~{}." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><msup><mi>ϕ</mi><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>⁣</mo><mo>*</mo></mrow></msup></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><msup><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>-</mo></msup></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><msup><mi>ϕ</mi><mn>0</mn></msup></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo rspace="5.8pt">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="9.1pt">,</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><msup><mi>χ</mi><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>⁣</mo><mo>*</mo></mrow></msup></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><msup><mi>ξ</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><msup><mi>χ</mi><mrow><mi/><mo>+</mo><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>χ</mi><mo>-</mo></msup></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><msup><mi>ξ</mi><mn>0</mn></msup></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><msup><mi>χ</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><msup><mi>χ</mi><mrow><mi/><mo>-</mo><mo>-</mo></mrow></msup></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>ξ</mi><mo>-</mo></msup></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><msup><mi>χ</mi><mn>0</mn></msup></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo rspace="5.8pt">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: where summations over $a,b = 1,2,3$ are understood, $\sigma$'s and $T$'s are respectively the Pauli matrices and the $3\times3$ matrix representation of the SU(2) generators, and
prevtext: The most general Higgs potential invariant under the global $SU(2)_L\times SU(2)_R\times U(1)_Y$ symmetry is
text:
\begin{align}
\begin{split}
V
=& \ \frac{1}{2} m_1^2 \, {\rm tr}[ \Phi^{\dagger} \Phi ] + 
\frac{1}{2} m_2^2 \, {\rm tr}[ \Delta^{\dagger} \Delta ]
 +  \lambda_1 \left( {\rm tr}[ \Phi^{\dagger} \Phi ] \right)^2 
 +  \lambda_2 \left( {\rm tr}[ \Delta^{\dagger} \Delta ] \right)^2 
\\
&
 +  \lambda_3 {\rm tr}\left[ \left( \Delta^{\dagger} \Delta \right)^2 \right] 
 +  \lambda_4 {\rm tr}[ \Phi^{\dagger} \Phi ] {\rm tr}[ \Delta^{\dagger} \Delta ]
 +  \lambda_5 {\rm tr}\left[ \Phi^{\dagger} \frac{\sigma^a}{2} \Phi \frac{\sigma^b}{2} \right] 
                  {\rm tr}[ \Delta^{\dagger} T^a \Delta T^b]
\\
 &+ \mu_1 {\rm tr}\left[ \Phi^{\dagger} \frac{\sigma^a}{2} \Phi \frac{\sigma^b}{2} \right]
                               (P^{\dagger} \Delta P)_{ab}
 + \mu_2 {\rm tr}[ \Delta^{\dagger} T^a \Delta T^b]
                               (P^{\dagger} \Delta P)_{ab} ~,
\end{split}
\label{potential}
\end{align}

\,{\rm tr}[\Phi^{\dagger}\Phi]+\frac{1}{2}m_{2}^{2}\,{\rm tr}[\Delta^{\dagger}%

\left({\rm tr}[\Delta^{\dagger}\Delta]\right)^{2}\\

\Delta]+\lambda_{5}{\rm tr}\left[\Phi^{\dagger}\frac{\sigma^{a}}{2}\Phi\frac{%
\sigma^{b}}{2}\right]{\rm tr}[\Delta^{\dagger}T^{a}\Delta T^{b}]\\
&\displaystyle+\mu_{1}{\rm tr}\left[\Phi^{\dagger}\frac{\sigma^{a}}{2}\Phi%
\frac{\sigma^{b}}{2}\right](P^{\dagger}\Delta P)_{ab}+\mu_{2}{\rm tr}[\Delta^{%

nexttext:
diagonalizes the adjoint representation of the SU(2) generators.  It is noted that all parameters in the Higgs potential are real and thus do not allow CP violation.


The triplet fields attain VEV's induced by the breakdown of electroweak symmetry.  With vacuum alignment in the triplet fields, $\langle \chi^0 \rangle = \langle \xi^0 \rangle \equiv v_\Delta$, the model preserves the custodial symmetry and keeps the electroweak $\rho$ parameter at unity at tree level.  The doublet and triplet VEV's satisfy the relation $v_{\Phi}^2+8v_{\Delta}^2 = (246~{\rm GeV})^2$.


The global $SU(2)_L\times SU(2)_R$ symmetry of the Higgs potential is explicitly broken by the Yukawa and the hypercharge interactions to the custodial $SU(2)_L$ symmetry, under which the $\Delta$ field is decomposed into the $\bf 5$, $\bf 3$, and $\bf 1$ representations while the $\Phi$ field is decomposed into the $\bf 3$ and $\bf 1$ representations.  The $\bf 5$ representation is CP-even.  Through the mixing angle $\beta$ defined by $\tan \beta \equiv v_{\Phi}/ \left( 2\sqrt{2}v_{\Delta} \right)$, the two $\bf 3$ representations mix with each other to give a physical CP-odd 3-plet $H_3$ and Goldstone bosons that become the longitudinal components of the $W$ and $Z$ bosons.  The two CP-even $\bf 1$ representations, on the other hand, mix with each other to give the 125-GeV SM-like Higgs boson $h$ and another singlet $H_1^0$ through another mixing angle $\alpha$.  Due to the custodial symmetry, particles within the same multiplet have the same mass, neglecting ${\cal O}(100)$~MeV mass difference among different charged states.  We therefore collectively denote the masses of physical 5-plet, 3-plet, and singlet exotic Higgs bosons by $m_{H_5}$, $m_{H_3}$, and $m_{H_1}$, respectively.



\begin{table}
\centering
\begin{tabular}{ccc}
\hline\hline
Higgs & ~~~~$\kappa_F$~~~~ 
& ~~~~~~~~~~~$\kappa_V$~~~~~~~~~~~ \\
\hline
$h$ & $\displaystyle \frac{\cos\alpha}{\sin\beta}$
& $\displaystyle \sin\beta\cos\alpha - \sqrt{\frac83} \cos\beta\sin\alpha$
\\
$H_1^0$ & $\displaystyle \frac{\sin\alpha}{\sin\beta}$ 
& $\displaystyle \sin\beta\sin\alpha + \sqrt{\frac83} \cos\beta\cos\alpha$
\\
$H_3^0$ & $i\eta_f\cot\beta$ 
& 0
\\
$H_5^0$ & 0 
& $\displaystyle \kappa_W = -\frac{\cos\beta}{\sqrt{3}}$ and 
$\displaystyle \kappa_Z = \frac{2\cos\beta}{\sqrt{3}}$
\\
\hline\hline
\end{tabular}
\\
\caption{Scaling factors for the couplings between the neutral Higgs bosons in the custodial Higgs triplet model and SM fermions and weak gauge bosons, as compared to the corresponding couplings of the SM Higgs boson.  $\eta_f = +1$ for up-type quarks and $-1$ for down-type quarks and charged leptons.
\label{coupling}}
\end{table}



Table~\ref{coupling} summarizes how the neutral Higgs bosons in the model couple to the SM fermions and weak gauge bosons, as compared to the corresponding couplings of the SM Higgs boson.  They are expressed in terms of the scaling factors defined as the ratios of Higgs couplings:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\begin{array}[]{ccc}-1&i&0\\
0&0&\sqrt{2}\\
1&i&0\end{array}\right)" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msqrt><mn>2</mn></msqrt></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mi>i</mi></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><msqrt><mn>2</mn></msqrt></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mi>i</mi></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

diagonalizes the adjoint representation of the SU(2) generators.  It is noted that all parameters in the Higgs potential are real and thus do not allow CP violation.


The triplet fields attain VEV's induced by the breakdown of electroweak symmetry.  With vacuum alignment in the triplet fields, $\langle \chi^0 \rangle = \langle \xi^0 \rangle \equiv v_\Delta$, the model preserves the custodial symmetry and keeps the electroweak $\rho$ parameter at unity at tree level.  The doublet and triplet VEV's satisfy the relation $v_{\Phi}^2+8v_{\Delta}^2 = (246~{\rm GeV})^2$.


The global $SU(2)_L\times SU(2)_R$ symmetry of the Higgs potential is explicitly broken by the Yukawa and the hypercharge interactions to the custodial $SU(2)_L$ symmetry, under which the $\Delta$ field is decomposed into the $\bf 5$, $\bf 3$, and $\bf 1$ representations while the $\Phi$ field is decomposed into the $\bf 3$ and $\bf 1$ representations.  The $\bf 5$ representation is CP-even.  Through the mixing angle $\beta$ defined by $\tan \beta \equiv v_{\Phi}/ \left( 2\sqrt{2}v_{\Delta} \right)$, the two $\bf 3$ representations mix with each other to give a physical CP-odd 3-plet $H_3$ and Goldstone bosons that become the longitudinal components of the $W$ and $Z$ bosons.  The two CP-even $\bf 1$ representations, on the other hand, mix with each other to give the 125-GeV SM-like Higgs boson $h$ and another singlet $H_1^0$ through another mixing angle $\alpha$.  Due to the custodial symmetry, particles within the same multiplet have the same mass, neglecting ${\cal O}(100)$~MeV mass difference among different charged states.  We therefore collectively denote the masses of physical 5-plet, 3-plet, and singlet exotic Higgs bosons by $m_{H_5}$, $m_{H_3}$, and $m_{H_1}$, respectively.

\centering
\begin{tabular}{ccc}
\hline\hline
Higgs & ~~~~$\kappa_F$~~~~ 
& ~~~~~~~~~~~$\kappa_V$~~~~~~~~~~~ \\
\hline
$h$ & $\displaystyle \frac{\cos\alpha}{\sin\beta}$
& $\displaystyle \sin\beta\cos\alpha - \sqrt{\frac83} \cos\beta\sin\alpha$
\\
$H_1^0$ & $\displaystyle \frac{\sin\alpha}{\sin\beta}$ 
& $\displaystyle \sin\beta\sin\alpha + \sqrt{\frac83} \cos\beta\cos\alpha$

& $\displaystyle \kappa_W = -\frac{\cos\beta}{\sqrt{3}}$ and

\\

\\
\caption{Scaling factors for the couplings between the neutral Higgs bosons in the custodial Higgs triplet model and SM fermions and weak gauge bosons, as compared to the corresponding couplings of the SM Higgs boson.  $\eta_f = +1$ for up-type quarks and $-1$ for down-type quarks and charged leptons.
\label{coupling}}

~{}~{}\kappa_{V}[\phi]=\frac{g_{\phi VV}}{g_{h_{SM}VV}}~{}," display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>κ</mi><mi>F</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>g</mi><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover></mrow></msub><msub><mi>g</mi><mrow><msub><mi>h</mi><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>M</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover></mrow></msub></mfrac></mstyle></mpadded></mrow><mo rspace="9.1pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>κ</mi><mi>V</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>g</mi><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>g</mi><mrow><msub><mi>h</mi><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>M</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>V</mi></mrow></msub></mfrac></mstyle></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
ATLAS also reported that the total decay width of the resonance $\Gamma_S \simeq 45$~GeV with $3.9\sigma$ local significance.  Although these data are not conclusive, it is nevertheless an amusing  exercise to see whether the singlet Higgs boson can possibly accommodate the data.


As in the case of $h$, the $H_1^0$ boson can be produced mainly through both GGF and VBF mechanisms at the LHC:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\sigma(pp\to S\to\gamma\gamma)" display="inline"><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>p</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>γ</mi><mi>γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=(5.8\pm 1.6)\text{ fb}." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>5.8</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>1.6</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> fb</mtext></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: In the narrow width approximation, the GGF production cross section of $H_1^0$ is
prevtext:
ATLAS also reported that the total decay width of the resonance $\Gamma_S \simeq 45$~GeV with $3.9\sigma$ local significance.  Although these data are not conclusive, it is nevertheless an amusing  exercise to see whether the singlet Higgs boson can possibly accommodate the data.


As in the case of $h$, the $H_1^0$ boson can be produced mainly through both GGF and VBF mechanisms at the LHC:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\sigma(pp\to H_{1})_{\text{total}}=\sigma(pp\to H_{1})_{\text{GGF}}+\sigma(pp%
\to H_{1})_{\text{VBF}}~{}." display="block"><mrow><mi>σ</mi><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>p</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mtext>total</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>σ</mi><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>p</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mtext>GGF</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>σ</mi><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>p</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mtext>VBF</mtext></msub></mpadded><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $\tau=m_{H_1}^2/s$ and $\sqrt s$ is the center-of-mass energy.  The parton luminosity factor for the $gg$ initial state $[\frac{1}{s}\frac{\partial L_{gg}}{\partial\tau}]$ is taken to be $0.97~(4.4)~ K_g\times10^3$~pb for the 8 (13)-TeV collisions, where the NLO K-factor $K_g \simeq 2$~\cite{Kfactor}.  A similar expression for the VBF can be obtained by replacing the partial width $\Gamma(H_1\to gg)$ and the parton luminosity factor $[\frac{1}{s}\frac{\partial L_{gg}}{\partial\tau}]$ respectively with $\Gamma(H_1\to WW)$ and the parton luminosity factor of the $WW$ initial state $[\frac{1}{s}\frac{\partial L_{WW}}{\partial\tau}]$.  The $WW$ luminosity factor is calculated to be 0.15 (0.36)~pb for the 8 (13)-TeV collisions.  The K-factor in this case is virtually 1~\cite{Kfactor}.


Even though $\Gamma(H_1^0 \to W^+W^-) > \Gamma(H_1^0 \to gg)$ for the parameter space of interest to us, the GGF production is still dominant due to the large $gg$ parton luminosity factor.   Since both the decay widths of $H_1^0$ to $gg$ and $WW$ only depend on $\alpha$ and $v_\Delta$, we thus superimpose red contours of the $H_1^0$ production cross section at the 13-TeV LHC in Fig.~\ref{chipptoH1}.  It is noted that the red curves are almost symmetric with respect to $\alpha = 0$, also reflecting the fact that the GGF production is dominant as its rate is proportional to $\sin^2\alpha$ from the top-quark loop contribution.  As $v_\Delta$ increases, $\cos\beta$ gets larger and so does the $H_1^0$-$W^+$-$W^-$ coupling, particularly when $\alpha \to 0$.  In this case the VBF production also becomes important, resulting in the red elliptic contours in the figure.  For fixed values of $(v_\Delta, \alpha)$, the total production rate of $H_1^0$ increases with the $pp$ collision energy.
 

Before fitting to the required diphoton rate at 13 TeV, we first consider the existing constraints on the production of the 750-GeV $H_1^0$ in the following channels using the 8-TeV data:
prevtext: In the narrow width approximation, the GGF production cross section of $H_1^0$ is
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\sigma(pp\to H_{1})_{\text{GGF}}=\frac{\pi^{2}}{8}\frac{\Gamma(H_%
{1}\to gg)}{M_{H_{1}}}\left[\frac{1}{s}\frac{\partial L_{gg}}{\partial\tau}%
\right]~{}," display="inline"><mrow><mi>σ</mi><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>p</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mtext>GGF</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msup><mi>π</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mn>8</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>→</mo><mi>g</mi><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><msub><mi>M</mi><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></msub></mfrac></mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>s</mi></mfrac></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>g</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo rspace="5.8pt">]</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
where $\tau=m_{H_1}^2/s$ and $\sqrt s$ is the center-of-mass energy.  The parton luminosity factor for the $gg$ initial state $[\frac{1}{s}\frac{\partial L_{gg}}{\partial\tau}]$ is taken to be $0.97~(4.4)~ K_g\times10^3$~pb for the 8 (13)-TeV collisions, where the NLO K-factor $K_g \simeq 2$~\cite{Kfactor}.  A similar expression for the VBF can be obtained by replacing the partial width $\Gamma(H_1\to gg)$ and the parton luminosity factor $[\frac{1}{s}\frac{\partial L_{gg}}{\partial\tau}]$ respectively with $\Gamma(H_1\to WW)$ and the parton luminosity factor of the $WW$ initial state $[\frac{1}{s}\frac{\partial L_{WW}}{\partial\tau}]$.  The $WW$ luminosity factor is calculated to be 0.15 (0.36)~pb for the 8 (13)-TeV collisions.  The K-factor in this case is virtually 1~\cite{Kfactor}.


Even though $\Gamma(H_1^0 \to W^+W^-) > \Gamma(H_1^0 \to gg)$ for the parameter space of interest to us, the GGF production is still dominant due to the large $gg$ parton luminosity factor.   Since both the decay widths of $H_1^0$ to $gg$ and $WW$ only depend on $\alpha$ and $v_\Delta$, we thus superimpose red contours of the $H_1^0$ production cross section at the 13-TeV LHC in Fig.~\ref{chipptoH1}.  It is noted that the red curves are almost symmetric with respect to $\alpha = 0$, also reflecting the fact that the GGF production is dominant as its rate is proportional to $\sin^2\alpha$ from the top-quark loop contribution.  As $v_\Delta$ increases, $\cos\beta$ gets larger and so does the $H_1^0$-$W^+$-$W^-$ coupling, particularly when $\alpha \to 0$.  In this case the VBF production also becomes important, resulting in the red elliptic contours in the figure.  For fixed values of $(v_\Delta, \alpha)$, the total production rate of $H_1^0$ increases with the $pp$ collision energy.
 

Before fitting to the required diphoton rate at 13 TeV, we first consider the existing constraints on the production of the 750-GeV $H_1^0$ in the following channels using the 8-TeV data:
text:
\begin{align}
\begin{split}
\sigma(pp\to H_1^0 \to\gamma\gamma)
&< 1.5~{\rm fb}~\mbox{\cite{diphoton1,diphoton2}} ~,

\\
\sigma(pp\to H_1^0 \to WW)
&< 40~{\rm fb}~\mbox{\cite{WW1,WW2}} ~,

\\
\sigma(pp\to H_1^0 \to ZZ)
&< 12~{\rm fb}~\mbox{\cite{ZZ}} ~,

\\
\sigma(pp\to H_1^0 \to Z\gamma)
&< 4.0~{\rm fb}~\mbox{\cite{Zphoton}} ~,

\\
\sigma(pp\to H_1^0 \to jj)
&< 2.5~{\rm fb}~\mbox{\cite{jj1,jj2}} ~.

\end{split}
\label{8TeV}
\end{align}
mathml: σ(pp→H10→γγ)<1.5⁢fb⁢[diphoton1, diphoton2],σ(pp→H10→WW)<40⁢fb⁢[WW1, WW2],σ(pp→H10→ZZ)<12⁢fb⁢[ZZ],σ(pp→H10→Zγ)<4.0⁢fb⁢[Zphoton],σ(pp→H10→jj)<2.5⁢fb⁢[jj1, jj2].
